column2: Standard setting / scheme management - Credibility (1st Dimension)

column5: Explanation of criteria

column4: * description of scheme owner and emphasis on whether it is owned by companies, or owned by a different group of stakeholders
column5: Green: The scheme is owned by a broad group of different stakeholders including Civil Society and workers / farmers orgnisations and is not owned by just companies; no Yellow or Red; Grey if not Green
column8: Business association Foreign Trade Association (FTA). All members are companies
column9: Business association Foreign Trade Association (FTA). All members are companies
column10: ETI Board members comprise corporate representatives, NGO and trade union representatives equally
column11: Business association of mostly retailers (GLOBALG.A.P. members vote the board, which in turn directs the Secretariat, Technical Commitees and Focus Groups)
column12: GSCP is part of the Consumer Goods Forum (CGF), which is a corporate association
column13: GRI is an independent organization, developing Sustainability Reporting Standards
column14:
Fair Labor Association FLA. FLA members are companies (47 brands and 19 suppliers), universities (around
200), and NGOs. FLA is governed by a board which comprises six representatives fromeach of the above categories.
column15: Social Accountability Initiative (SAI). SAI is not a members organisation. The SAI Board of Directors (11 member) is the highest decision making body for SAI operations, while the SAI multi-stakeholder Advisory Board is responsible for the development and interpretation of the standard.
column16: SAI Platform is registred as an association. Active members are food industry companies
column17: Juice industry association SGF International e.V.. Members of SGF are trade associations, retailers and comapnies (599)
column18: No organization structure comparable to other schemes, because EC regulation - but responsibilities and national authorities are defined
column19: Since 2014 the scheme is owned by IMOgroup AG, a provider for international inspection and certfication services
column20: Fairtrade International. Fairtrade members are national fairtrade organisation (23) and producer networks (3). Both constitutencies have 50% of decision-making power
column21: Forest Stewardship Council FSC. FSC membership is open to organisations and individuals. Members (853) join FSC through one of the three chambers - environmental, social or economic. Decision-making power in the general assembly is divided up equally between the chambers. National offices follow the same structure
column22: Global Coffee Platform. 4C Association for a Better Coffee World was split into two in March 2016, forming the standard-setting body GCF and Coffee Assurance Service (CAS), responsible for the scheme's verification functions
column23: MSC. Three governance bodies: Board of Trustees (for strategic direction), which also includes represenatives from the Technical Advisory Board (experts on marine science, policy and saefood supply chains) and the Stakeholder Council (fishing organisations, NGOs, consumer groups, etc.)
column24: Sustainabel Agricultural Network (SAN) and Rainforest Alliance (RA). SAN's 10 members are NGOs working on conservation of biodiversity and rural development. RA is governed by a board of directors
column25: Roundtable of Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). RSPO members include palm oil producers (148), processors or traders (431), consumer goods manufacturers (585), retailers (62), banks/investors (15), an denvironmental and social NGOs (45)
column26: UTZ Foundation. UTZ members are producers and supply chain actors (brands, processors, retailers). UTZ is governed by a supervisory board. The board is a multi-stakeholder body members of which are drawn from the following groups: production; supply chain, civil society, and trade unions. Supervisory board members however do not represent  their stakeholder groupbut rather act in the overall interests of UTZ+

column3: Are trade unions represented in the scheme's decision-making bodies?
column5: Red: Trade unions do not have any power of decision or other permanent role in the scheme. However, they may be hear e.g. when the scheme's criteria are drafted or revised. Yellow: Trade unions are represented in permanent advisory bodies, but not in decision-making bodies; Green: Trade unions are represented in the scheme's decision-making bodies
column10: Yes, balanced representation of trade unions in the Board
column12: No, only CEOs from retailers and manufactures
column13: Multi-stakeholde initiative but no balanced representation of trade unions in all decision making bodies
column15: Yes, trade unions are represented on the Advisory Board and the Standards Committee, whcih is responsible for revising and providing interpretation of the standard
column16: No, only food industry representatives in Executive Committee
column18: Indirect participation of stakeholders, but not transparent and balanced
column19: No, but revision process in based on a broad multi-stakholder consultation
column20: Yes, through membership in national Fair trade organisations. Members of the permanent Workers Rights Advisory Committee also include representatives from the global trade union movement
column21: Yes, MSI with trade union representation
column22: Yes, MSI with trade union representation
column23: MSI with broad stakeholder participation, but no trade union representation in decision making bodies

column5: - An overview of quantitative information on the income sources or financing structure of the scheme (e.g. potentially including type of funding (i.e. financial, assets, manpower, etc), name of funders, amount or %-distribution of income sources). This could be provided in the form of an annex to annual reports.
column8: membership fees range between 3,000€ and 30,000€ depending on turnover; certification costs are not made available
column9: membership fees range between 3,000€ and 30,000€ depending on turnover; certification costs are not made available
column10: membership fees depending on turnover; foudation stage members pay 1,000€; auditing costs are not made available
column11: Yes, GLOBALG.A.P. is mailnly financed by licensing (81%) and membership fees (10%)
column12: No, the financial structure of CGF is not publicly available
column13: Yes, publicly available on website (annual reports)
column14:
Membership fees,
government grants,
foundations, audit fees
(when FLA audit teams
are used).
column15: Yes, public disclosure available on website; audit costs up to $2,500
column16: No, only very brief financial income/expenditure overview in annual report
column17: Yes (in part), financing through membership fees between €3,000 and €50,000
column19: Yes, on request. The administration and management of the scheme is financed exclusively by the revenue from certification business
column20: yes, see annual report, mainly financed by licensing operation
column21: Yes, The organization mainly finances itself through license fees collected from certification bodys  (ca.94% in 2013)
column22: Quantitative information on the income sources available. Major part of revenues is generated by membership fees
column23: yes, online, main financing through licensing (73%) and donations (24%)
column24: yes, publicly available financial statement. Scheme is alsmost exclusively financed by licensing
column25: yes, on request, mainly financed by subscription of members and contributions from sustainable palm oil trade
column26: yes, programme is primarily financed by licensing and membership fees

column2: Scoring with points (Green = 2; Yellow = 1;  Red = 0; Grey =  No scoring)

column3: Are the long-term imapcts of the scheme's implementation systematically monitored? Have indicators been identified for the assessment of impacts?
column5: Red: The scheme does not systematically monitor the long-term impacts of ist work; Yellow: The scheme monitors impacs, but does not have set indicators and/or ist indicators are inadequate and/or the impacts are not assessed systematically; Green: The scheme monitors the impacts of its work using indicators of a high standard
column7: wird nur gezählt, wo es Angaben gibt u Resultat bezieht sich nur auf anwendbareFragen / Bereiche
column9: No, but in 2010 an impact study was conducted regarding BSCI in the food industry;
column10: No, ETI has conducted a thorough  long-term impact assessment in 2003 - 2006 on whether workers really benefit, including case studies on specific countries, Yet, regular impact assessments are not  conducted or published
column14:
FLA is currently piloting
a new approach to reaccreditation
of member
companies previously
accredited by the
organisation with an
eye to a more robust
evaluation of impact
on working conditions.
FLA also conducts innovation
projects to
measure impacts, e.g.
gender equality in cocoa
production in Côte
d’Ivoire and child labour
in hazelnut production
in Turkey.
column15: SAI is beginning to conduct impact assessments with the revision of the Standard and SAI's increased involvement through Social Fingerprint, a programme designed to measure and improve social performance
column17: No. The system is currently under review
column19: A FT Action Plan and Impact Assessment is required by each operation which will serve as a base for a more detailed internal monitoring on impact and progress.
column20: Yes; indicators pertain to enhanced access to fair trading conditions and fair prices for small producer organisations; increased investment in small producers, their organisations and communities; stronger, well managed organisations for small producers, etc.
column21: FSC reports on impacts in accordance with ISEAL Impacts Code which requires an analysis of short-term and long-term outcomes. Reports on the results of their evaluations are available publicly.
column23: MSC reports on impacts in accordance with ISEAL Impacts Code which requires an analysis of short-term and long-term outcomes. Reports on the results of their evaluations are available publicly.
column24: Yes, indicators pertain to biodiversity conservation; effective production of crops and livestock; improved livelihoods for local communities; and, effective management enabling adaptation to changing conditions
column25: An RSPO impact report is published biannually in accordance with ISEAL requirements.
column26: Yes, indicators are: long-term economic viability and increased resilience of farms; farmers make a living income & have a decent standard of living, workers earn a living wage; better health; children go to school; natural resources are safeguarded; reduced GHG emissions; and contribution to biodiversit y protection

column3: Does the scheme owner use the results of monitoring and evaluation for learning and improvements to its programme and are results from M&E made available?
column5: Red: The scheme does not feed in the results of monitoring & evaluation in its internal processes ; Yellow:  The scheme regularly feeds in the results of monitoring & evaluation in its internal processes, e.g. records of inclusion on the agenda of meetings, policy for when results are considered; Green: The scheme regularly feeds in the results of monitoring & evaluation in its internal processes and those information are made publicaly available
column8: yes,  but not publicly available (focus on sharing information within ist member network). Internal Monitoring through FTA Sustainability Dashboard which is available to all members. The system is used for benchmarking supply chain acitities and performance
column9: yes, but not publicly available. Also internal monitoring is based on voluntary disclosure of information by its participants. common auditing protocol and programme; database platform where BSCI participants can map their supply chains, sharing information on suppliers and their auditing results; and a global capactiy building platform
column10: yes, monitoring,e valuation and learning framework is key to the development of the scheme and documents like impact reports and evaluations are planned to published through International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI)
column11: yes, but not publicly available (only for participants with access to the intenal data base)
column13: Yes, but sustainability reports are publicly accessible in the Sustainability Disclosure Database only on a voluntary basis
column14: The scheme regularly feeds in the results of monitoring & evaluation in its internal processes and those information are made publicaly available
column16: No, but eexternal stakeholders are encouraged to participate in the development and review process of the FSA)
column19: Yes, systematic and continuous improvement, regular revision process based on multi-stakeholder participation and benchmarking against GSCP in order to identify strength and potentials for improvements
column20: Regular monitoring and evaluation, including the publishing of results
column21: FSC has a Monitoring and Evaluation programme since 2013 which serves two main purposes: One is organizational learning; the other is communication of outcomes and impacts reports available. All related documents are available on the website.
column23: The M&E program focuses on critical information needs and research gaps associated with the environmental impacts and commercial reach of MSC certification. Data and information gathered and analysed are used to inform management decisions; promote the benefits of the MSC program to stakeholders, funders and consumers; underpin continual improvement; and, demonstrate credibility of the MSC program.
column24: yes, regular monitoring and evaluation and public reporting
column25: yes, regular monitoring and evaluation, including public reporting
column26: yes, regular monitoring and evaluation which is also used to further develop the standard

column3: Risk Assessment, Environmental or Human Rights Due Diligence
column4: Are the companies that are being audited required to undertake either human rights due diligence or systematic risk assessments in their supply chain? The question does not apply to primary production
column5: Red: The companies that are being audited are not required to exercise human rights due diligence or systematic risk assessments; Yellow: The compaanies that are being audited have been advised to exercise human rights due diligence or systematic risk assessments, but this is not monitored; Green: The companies that are being audited are required to exercise huamn rights due diligene or systematic risk assessments.
column8: Supply Chain Analysis includes risk assessment but only part of self-assessment, and only limited scope
column9: Risk assessment primarily conducted on health and security, discrmination, and corruption. No explicit tools for human rights due diligence throuhout the whole supply chain
column10: Yes, ETI urges all member companies to conduct human rights due diligence and has adopted a holistic framework for implementing due dilgence throughout the supply chain
column11: Written risk assessments, focusing on workers’ health and safety, but no human rights due diligence; Also each producer has a wildlife management and conservation plan that acknowledges the impact of farming on the environment, environmental risk assessments are conducted.
column12:
Risk assessments to identify risk to workers’ rights, safety and welfare at least for first tier or direct supplier, including kay stakeholder input
Human rights impact assessments within supply chain, including refined risk assessment methodology to identify issues at lower levels of the supply chain is considered as “advanced step” in Reference tool on Supply Chain Social Perfomance Management Systems.
column14:
In selecting factories
for assessment by
FLA, FLA assigns risk
weights to countries
depending on the local
labour rights environment.
As a result, factories
in high risk countries
(e.g. Bangaladesh,
China are oversampled
in the selection.
column15:
Yes, human rights due
diligence over supply
chain, including the
selection of new suppliers/
subcontractors,
private employment
agencies and subsuppliers
is required.
Performance related to
this requirement is assessed
during the audit.
column17:
No. However, SGF/IRMA
Code of Conduct requires
that IRMA certified
suppliers transmit
social standards to
their fresh fruit suppliers
and packaging
houses. The process is
currently under review.
column19: The Standard requires compliance with standard requirements (including human rights) along the entire supply chain. No explicit human rights due diligence mechanism.

column2: Scoring with points (Green = 2; Yellow = 1; Red = 0; Grey =  No scoring)

column3: Who monitors the implementation of criteria?
column5: Red: The compnay that is being audited monitors its own activities through self-assessment (first-party monitoring) or no compolsury second- or third-party audit; Yellow: Audits are realised through second-party; Green: Audits are conducted by a third-party service provider or a independent verification.
column10: second-party (ETI board randomly checks 20% of annual reports - no ETI audits, but ETI suggests independent verification bodies to member companies
column12: N.A., because the standard is neither a monitoring initiative, nor will it undertake accreditation or certification activities
column13: Reporting is not based on audits, but on modular standards, comprising requirements, recommendations, and guidane
column14:
Member companies
monitor production facilities,
FLA monitors
member companies and independent verification.
column16:
Self-assessment. If a company is going to make public claims about the FSA per
formance score (bronze/silver/gold) of their suppliers  using 
Option 1, verification 
by third-party auditing is
required
column17: The auditor will yearly check compliance of one social and one environmental criterion during the regular SGF audit. In the certificate (regarding sustainability aspects) SGF certifies 1) commitment to the standard and 2) compliance in two selected control points (no child labour in the factory; waste water treatment in place).
column22: Producer managing units submit annual self-assessments to Coffee Assurance Services; self-assessments are verified every three years by third party service providers.

column3: At least how often do clients undergo a full audit process?
column4: 1 year or less / 1-2 years / 2-3 years / 4-5 years / 5 years or more / Not applicable
column5:
--> Only applicable if the scheme requires audits. This question does not apply to CoC audits.

- The scheme owner defines this requirement in certification requirements/methodologies, or in the contract/agreement between the scheme owner and the AB, or in a separate accreditation manual 

This question refers to external audits. In a full audit process, all requirements of the standard and the whole system of the client that is to be assessed are verified. This would usually include re-certification audits but not necessarily surveillance audits in case these are less rigorous. In the response, state the least possible frequency, i.e. if an interval can be skipped for certain clients, e.g. based on a risk assessment, the frequency shall be reduced (see also criterion on risk-based audit frequency)
column9: every 2 years, depending on scoring also more often
column10: ETI does not carry out -audits and -verifications, but recommends the member companies only independent verifying authorities
column11: Annual announced and unannounced third-party audits
column12: no requirements for regular audits,see above
column14:
FLA member companies
are required to
submit five percent of
their applicable supply
chain to annual assessment
by the FLA
– these are physical
audits.

Semi-annual surveillance audits are conducted; at least one 
in the first three years must be unannounced
column16: Only if company wishes to make claims about FSA performance
column18: annual audits from accredited third-party auditors
column19: annual complete on-site audit, conducted by an independent third-party
column20:
annual surveillance audits, and re-assessment should commence by the fourth
anniversary of an existing certificate, so that the new
certificate can continue from the five year expiry of the
existing certificate.
column22: 3 year field verfication cycle and annual update by 4C Units
column23: annual audits, full auditing and certification process every 5 years
column24: two audits within 3 year certification period, third party audit
column25: physcial audit every 5 years, annual surveillance audit, third party audits by ASI

column3: Does the auditing process involve interviews with workers? Are interviews carried out on-site or off-site?
column5: Red: Interviews with workers are not a compulsory part of audits. Yellow: Workers are interviewed as part of the audit process, but the interviews is carried out mainly on-site at the production facility. Green: Workers must be interviewed as part of the audit process. Interviews or at least some of the interviews must be carried out off-site or without management beeing present

Yes, auditors must interview
management,
particularly managers
in charge of Human
Resources and Occupational
Health and

representative, internal
auditors and workers.
Interviews can be
conducted on-site or
off-site.

No, GRASP auditor also conducts an interview with the workers’

use FLA audit methodology and audit teams for assessing their suppliers'
compliance.

column19: Yes, balanced representation (contract types, gender, etc.) and interview take place in formal (e.g. meeting room) or informal setting (e,g. workplace) without any management or supervisory staff being present. Offsite interviews are not mandatory, but should be especially considered in case of suspected serious infringement of workers rights

column3: Are auditors required to solicit external stakeholder input (like local trade unions or NGOs) during the audit process?
column5: --> Only applicable if the scheme requires audits. This question does not apply to CoC audits. Red: External stakeholder from local trade unions and/or NGOs during audit process input is not required; Yellow: External stakeholder input from local trade unions and/or NGOs is recommended/optional during audits; Green: External stakeholder input from local trade unions and/or NGOs is required during audits
column14: External stakeholder input is required during audits
column19: Yes (in part): Auditors may contact local organizations and officials and conduct interviews with neighbors and third-parties to further validate the findings of the audit

column3: Compliance Technical Assistance, beyond technical and Access to finance
column4: Does the scheme provide access to technical assistance for compliance with the standard?  Does the scheme provide access to technical assistance beyond compliance with the standard? Does the scheme provide access to finance for enterprises seeking certification?
column5: Red: If no system or strategy is provided.
column8: BEPI offers technical assistance and training for both participants and producers, particularly on BEPI implementation.
column9: BSCI offers technical assistance and trainings to increase suppliers’ knowledge and skills with regard to social compliance. These training sessions are open for the suppliers of all BSCI Participants.
column10: ETI offers free of charge trainings and guidance in implementing the criteria.
column11: yes, access to GLOBALG.A.P data base and all ist tools, access to customized statistics, and client-based monitoring tools of the database, trainings
column12: offers a suite of open source  best practice Reference tools (for social, environment, and auditing)
column13: offers reporting principles, services to support reporting organizations as well as training and coaching
column14:
FLA provides assistance
to companies
in developing specific
company action plans
in response to an assessment.
column15: SAI provides free of charge online access to information and documents that help companies understand the requirements of the SA8000 standard. SAI also offers a wide range of services and technical assistance including workshops and training seminars - See more at: http://www.standardsmap.org/review.aspx?standards=58#sthash.XBzTz4wh.dpuf
column16: Yes, SAI Platfomr's Principles and Practices are available on the website, annual seminars and sunstainability webinars to member companies and interested stakeholders, specific training modules (e.g. on implementing sunstainable agricultural practices)
column19:
is no financial support to operations seeking certification foreseen by the scheme holder.  Standard requires the support of the producer operation by the Fair Trade buyer in terms of long-term partnership, definition of volume forecast, definition of floor prices and regular communication and support between buyer and producer. 
In case of buying from small-holders, the Fair Trade buyer needs to grant pre-payment if requested.
column20: yes,financial support and conulting concerning standard implementation as well as various cooperation programmes
column22: no info, because currently under transition
column23: yes, several capacity building programmes and improvement tools
column24: SAN provides free of charge online support services including learning modules and access to information on certification process. Training activities for producers are also facilitated in some countries by SAN members.
column25: training and education programmes, funding provisions
column26: yes, through training and capactiy building

column3: Does the scheme have a traceability system that enables checking of product flow between links of the supply chain?
column5:
--> only applicable if claims are made regarding the origin of certain ingredients or products (CoC is required)

Red: There is no traceability system that enables checking the product flow between links of the supply chain,Yellow: A traceability system is in place but it is (1) not OR only in part publicly available or (2) based on mass Balance only ; Green: A traceability system schelf to farm is in place, compulsory and publicly available (e.g. on website).

column14: A traceability system is in place.
column17: Yes, but only internal and not publicly available
column20: yes, traceability of origin through Fair Trade Code on website
column21: yes, there is a unique license number on every certified product or on its invoice, which provides the ability to trace back the product to its least manufacturing company.
column22: yes (in part), but not publicly availble, license number serves the purpose to track volumes of coffee between 4C unit and final buyer.

ny.  Not publicly availble

column3: Are audit reports or audit results available to the public?
column5:
Red: Audit reports and audit results are not available to the public. Yellow: Audit reports are not available to the public, but
a general summary of the report and/or audit results are available to the public. Green: Audit reports and audit results are available to the public.
column9: Audit reports are not available to the public, but a general summary of the  audit results is available to the public.
column10: yes, at least some documents and further plans to  published through International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) and reports on the progress and deficiencies of the member companies are published.
column11: • The database stores and connects the assessment and certification data, the GLOBALG.A.P. Number (GGN), a 13-digit number uniquely identifies each producer and individual member of a producer group in the GLOBALG.A.P. Database – also with a public search system. The system provides instant and complete accessibility of registration and status data of every producer and product for all options.
column14: Audit reports and results are available to the public, including list of 1st tier suppliers.
column19: • Every certified operation is published on the Fair for Life website with an overview of their overall performance rating and evaluation of social impact together with information on the companies’ particular achievements, use of the Fair Trade Development Premium and Social & Fair Trade activities
column23: Yes, MSC has a public review of draft report which makes assessment reports availble for public comments for 30 days on the website
column24: Yes, the summaries of audit results are public
column25: Yes, the summaries of audit results are public

column3: How large a portion of raw materials must be in accordance with criteria before a claim of responsibility can be made?
column5: Red: A consumer product can carry the scheme’s logo or a text that references it, even when the product is less than 10 per cent certifi ed or audited. Yellow: A consumer product can carry the scheme’s logo or a text that references it, when the product is at least 30 per cent certifi ed or audited. Green: A consumer product can carry the scheme’s logo or a text that references it, when the product is at least 80 per cent certifi ed or audited.
column19: Singleingredient product  100%, At least 80% of all agricultural ingredients are certified Fair Trade quality, the fair trade content shall be displayed on the label, e.g. under the ingredient list,
